titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to Foreign Mission School Collection
1799-2015
MS 038 MS 038
titlestmt.author: Processed by Zachary Keith

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2017-02-02 07:48:14 -0800.

did.langmaterial: The language of the materials is English
did.abstract: The Foreign Mission School Operated from 1817 to 1826 and educated 100 pupils from diverse backgrounds. The collection encompasses administrative, educational, and printed materials.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: This collection was compiled over many years by members of the Cornwall Historical Society

archdesc.userestrict:

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Foreign Mission School Collection ; MS038; box number; folder number; Cornwall Historical Society

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Foreign Mission School was established in 1817 in Cornwall, Connecticut. Approximately 100 pupils were educated at the Foreign Mission School during its near 10 years of operation. The Foreign Mission School was a bold new venture in evangelism: to convert, and educate young men, predominantly people of color, from indigenous cultures around the world, and send them home to be native preachers, translators, teachers, and health workers. It was established by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions (ABCFM), who held the view that Christianity and civilization were inseparable gifts to be brought to non-christians.The students of the Foreign Mission School brought 24 different native languages to Cornwall and represented such places as Hawaii, China, and Greece.

The main subject taught at the Foreign Mission School was christian religion, though other subjects were covered as well. As part of their christian education students attended weekly services and their progress was reviewed annually at a public examination.

The founding pupil was Heneri Opukahaia, an unlettered 18-year-old Hawaiian refugee from a blood feud, left by a ship's captain in wintry New Haven in 1810. His circumstances inspired efforts to shelter and educate him and others, some from American Indian tribes, many displaced from great distances - Asia, Europe, Polynesia, and Africa - as missionaries. As an exponent of the ABCFM's vision, he traveled widely to preach its message, but he died in Cornwall at 26 before he could return home as a missionary. In 1993, the remains of Obookiah were exhumed and returned to Hawaii.

In time, questions were raised about this method of education and evangelization. Support for the Foreign Mission School had been slowly declining when the marriages of two Cornwall girls with Cherokee students caused a local furor and public scandal, this gave the ABCFM an opportunity to close the Foreign Mission School in 1826.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Foreign Mission School Collection encompasses material relating to and about the Foreign Mission School. The collection is organized into seven series, correspondence, legal materials, administrative materials, print materials, photohraphic and print images, realia, and miscellaneous.

The Correspondence series is comprised of letters inquiring about the Foreign Mission School and letters written by those who attended or were in some other way involved with the Foreign Mission School.
The Legal Materials in the collection are marriage certificates, land deeds, and census materials.
The materials in the Administrative series relate to the running of the Foreign Mission School.

The print materials includes many volumes of books used by students at the Forieng Mission School as well as newspapers and newsclippings from the time of the Foreign Mission School through the early 2000s.
The Photographs and Printed Images series contains mostly 20th century images of commemorations of the Foreign Mission School. There are also some 19th century lithographs.
The Realia series is comprised of gifts from commemoration celebrations, printing plates, and a lock of hair.
The Miscellaneous materials is made up of collections of research notes, recollections, and geneologies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by subject/author heading then chronologically within each subject/author heading.
The files are grouped into 7 series:

did.unittitle: Deacon Lorrain Loomis to Photius Fisk
W. H. Miner to Rev. John Pierpont

odd.head: General
odd.p: Certificates for: John Ridge and Sally Northrup, Steven J Gold and Sarah F. Calhoun and Elias Boudinot and Harriet Gold.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials include: 1799 deed for town to build a school, American Board (which owned school) deed to Frederick Kellogg, Frederick Kellogg deed to the First Eclesiastical Society, notes on Seth Piece transaction, and copious photocopies of town record books.

did.unittitle: Census of the Eastern Cherokee Nation

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials are photocopies, and also include photocopies of some Mary C. Boudinot correspondence, her aid petition and the approval certificate.

did.unittitle: Last Will and Testament of Elias Boudinot

odd.head: General
odd.p: This is the last will and testament of New Jersey merchant Elias Boudinot who sponsored the Cherokee student later called Elias Boudinot, and heavily supported missionary activities.

did.unittitle: Annual Meeting Programs and Related Materials

odd.head: General
odd.p: Program for annual meeting 1814 and 1820; George Weed chatechism book (written by Weed); book of poems and correspondence.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Two photocopied pages of and a letter related to a book called the Chinese Memory Book, in which the name of a former Foreign Mission School student appears.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Sermon was given in Boston to the ABCFM.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Given to the Foreign Missionary Society of Litchfield County.

did.unittitle: A Narrative of Five Youth from the Sandwich Islands

odd.head: General
odd.p: Given at the Annual Exams at the Foreign Mission School.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Student of the Foreign Mission School from the Marquesas, who died while a student at the Foreign Mission School.

did.unittitle: How the Gospel came to Hawaii

odd.head: General
odd.p: One pamphlet titled "Obookiah, a native of Owyhee", and one handbook from the Henry Obookiah School in Hilo, Hawaii.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: pamphlet for the Mariner's Church in San Francisco, California, pamphlet for historic missionary housing in Honolulu, and one brochure for a walking tour of monarchy promonade in Honolulu, Hawaii.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: postcard of Hawaii, part of a children's book on Hawaiian history, an article on Union Congregational Church in Wailuku, Hawaii, memo regarding Hawaiian visitors to CHS and two excerpts from missionary journals.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Conducted by Nicholas Bellantoni.

did.unittitle: The First Foreign School in America

odd.head: General

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: Longfellow Memorial Association certificate, poems, and a commission from the President of the Greek Republic.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: book of correspondence to Hawaiian students that had returned home, Daggett family genealogic information, and Daggett's master's thesis.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: biographical information on John Ridge's father, notes on Elias Boudinot, receit, Religious journal receipts for Religious Intelligencer, Order form for the Pilgrim Series, notes on the founding of the Foreign Mission School, manuscript on the life of Henry Obookiah and copies of a typescript of a piece titled "The Foreign Mission School.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: notes by E.C. Starr on Everest family, and two copies of a sermon delivered by Everest in Windham Connecticut.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Cowles notes about her personal recollections of Henry Obookiah and the Foreign Mission School.

odd.head: General
odd.p: T.S. Gold, the younger's, speech about Cornwall industry given at the Falls Village Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Excerpt from The History of Goshen

odd.head: General
odd.p: Excerpt is regarding ministers related to the foreign mission movement, specifically that Joseph Harvey of Goshen was instumental in getting the Foreign Mission School established in Litchfield County.

did.unittitle: Cupid helped to close Cornwall mission school

odd.head: General
odd.p: Typescript about the controversial marriages that occured between students of the Foreign Mission School and local women.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Appeared in the WBM 150th Anniversary Edition; preface is about Henry Obookiah.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Pettibone's notes on the history of the Foreign Mission School being started and information on Deacon Lorrain Loomis, steward of the Foreign Mission School.

odd.head: General
odd.p: A hymn sung at the 50th anniversary of Bingham's ordination as a missionary in Goshen, CT.

did.unittitle: Transcript of Poem about Henry Obookiah

odd.head: General

odd.head: General
odd.p: Materials include: programs, receipts, a play and speeches.

did.unittitle: Invitation to Obookiah Memorial Ceremony in Hawaii
Description of Journey of Adam Hodgson

odd.head: General
odd.p: Notes, in modern script, of the travels of Adam Hodgson, a British man from Liverpool, through New England and the southern Cherokee settlements.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Lists of citations for Foreign Mission School in different collections and print works.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Foreign Mission School experts research notes relating to various aspects of the foreign mission school.
